Yellow and blue make black. If it were blue liquid (and not cyan) then it would filter out red and green light allowing only blue light to pass through it. A Yellow liquid blocks out Blue light and only allows red and green light to pass through it. combine the two and you have a liquid that blocks red, green and blue light making it appear black. But, if you used cyan liquid instead of blue, then cyan liquid blocks only red light allowing green and blue light to pass through. And since yellow liquid also allows green light to pass through it, the liquid would appear green.
Also, the 'S' pipe is banned in many areas not because it's more likely to get clogged up, but because it's more likely to siphon out the water trapped in the elbow water trap and break the vapor lock allowing sewer gases into the home.

What about composting toilets? With increasing pressure on water supplies (ask a Californian...), we should be recycling our waste and using it to enrich our soils. I've heard of "black soil" in the Amazon, which increased the fertility of the soil and was, I believe, created from composting human waste. I know that these days it's illegal (in the UK at least) to fertilize fields with untreated human waste due to the risk of diseases spreading, but I'm sure composting could/does overcome those problems. Also, sawdust used in composting toilets is a renewable resource; tree planting programmes throughout the world would be beneficial in many ways, from human employment to habitat conservation. I hope I'm not too "off the wall"; I'm only an ordinary person tacking together ideas generated from information I've come across here and there; but it seems to me i) we should be discouraging flush toilets as it's a criminal waste of a value-added resource and ii) we should be using our waste constructively. If you want to learn much more about human waste, get a cruising boat, one with a marine toilet called a "head".  Pretty much every one stores the "stuff" in a 'holding tank' which can be emptied by a big vacuum called a pump-out station, which ideally is then routed to a municipal treatment plant or a BIG septic system. Surprisingly, a proper holding tank's contents are not too smelly, as aerobic bacteria are properly supplied with air to do their work.  Smells like really rich soil, since that's what it is.

In Taiwan, many public bathrooms having a spray bottle full of ethanol alcohol or a spray dispenser, in lieu of paper seat cover. You either spray the set and wipe it with some toilet paper, or spray a little bit on the TP to wipe the seat. Much more sensible since paper seat covers do pick up things from the toilet plume. It's also funny that some people disagree on which is better, spraying the seat or spraying the paper. IMO the former is cleaner but it makes the seat super cold when you park your butt on it....

I think it's time for an update on how we handle human and animal manure. Mixing poop with our fresh drinking water is just plain wasteful.
We are depleting our valuable soils by not returning nutrients like selenium to the soil.
Also, we use very toxic chemicals to clean our toilets, and this gets added to the drinking water, too. All of which ends up back in the very same lakes streams and aquifers that we take our drinking water from.
In our city, we made the bad choice to combine our rainwater sewers with our wastewater sewage. This was to save money at the time, but has caused a huge, massively expensive problem in the present day. Now every time it rains hard, raw sewage gets dumped into our freshwater lake......from which we get our city water.
Furthermore, when cancer patients flush, extremely toxic chemotherapy drugs, which cause cancer, ends up in our water, and the water treatment plants were never designed to remove such things as drugs, hormones, and antibiotics.
We have to add a further toxic chemical, chlorine, which reacts with other things in the water, creating further toxins.
Chlorine interferes with thyroid hormones, causing us trouble regulating our metabolisms.
Fluoride also interferes with thyroid hormones. They add it as an antibiotic, but it is toxic to your bones and thyroid.

In nature, urine is naturally mostly sterile, and is a great nutrient for plants, especially when diluted with rainwater. Manure is very biodegradable and this works best when it is not put directly into water, unless you are a fish.

We need a system where we can use grey water to mix with the urine, and return it to the soil, in some way that plants have access to it. And we need a way to keep the manure out of our water, and compost it safely to return the essential nutrients to the soil, without contaminating it on the way with toxic cleaning chemicals, and antibiotics ("sanitizers").

Everybody says"Eewww! Put urine and poop on the soil...". But we are putting it in our water, which when diluted, allows it to leech into our groundwater, leaking into our wells, and contaminating our fresh water. That's worse. Poop is biologically safe when composted. (Even though it's still got drugs in it, if you are using them.)

For millions of years plants and animals have recycled literally everything: sun, air, water, dirt. We humans need to relearn how to do this without creating a toxic mess.
